awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Infrastructure Management under Model Uncertainty:  Adaptive Sequential Learning and Decision Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Maintenance and operation of interconnected infrastructures, including transportation and energy systems, are critical to provide adequate levels of safety and functionality to society. Critical decisions must be made about aging infrastructures under high uncertainty about the current condition of their components, their evolution, and the results of maintenance actions. As sensors, robotic inspectors, communication and computation become cheaper and more reliable, their use can be integrated into infrastructure management to improve maintenance policies and reduce uncertainty, risk and overall management cost. Full exploitation of this potential requires a change in paradigm in how we model and approach infrastructure decision making, and how novel computational methods may be adopted and extended in statistical inference and sequential optimization for managing infrastructure systems. This CAREER award exploits the interdependency among sensor deployment, probabilistic inference and decision making on maintenance and operation by developing advanced models and algorithms that would ultimately result in enhanced decision making for maintenance and operation purposes and reduced costs. The research will test the developed framework on three case studies including wind farms, networks of gas pipelines, and networks of bridges, in collaboration with companies that manage systems and develop software. The same framework underpinning the project research also forms the basis for a pedagogic approach on infrastructure management based on active, situated-learning activities, in which games will be developed to involve K-12 and college students with assigned roles as virtual infrastructure managers in an interactive environment. The PI will work closely with Carnegie Mellon's SEE (Summer Engineering Experience for Girls) program to inspire interest in risk analysis and infrastructure systems decision making.   

This project's goal is to develop scalable algorithms for long-term decision-making under persistent model uncertainty. These algorithms will target decisions about not only operation and maintenance of infrastructure systems, but also about the gathering of further information: placing sensors, scheduling inspections, planning tests and experimenting with new technologies for operation and sensing. By sequential iterations of learning and acting, managers can adaptively optimize resource allocation. Optimization becomes more complex, but with higher pay-off, when focusing on large interconnected systems: when numerous infrastructure components are statistically interdependent, because of spatial proximity, common stressors, or common dynamic models, information can propagate across them. This allows observations collected in one location to also be useful for inferring the conditions of others and, more importantly, the higher-level system evolution model. By identifying locations and components that deserve inspections, the agent can sequentially adapt the exploration of the system, avoid costly over-instrumentation, and guide management towards a sustainable use of the limited resources. To develop these approaches, this project will make use of Bayesian hierarchical modeling, random field modeling, pre-posterior and value-of-information analysis, sub-modularity analysis, approximate dynamic programming for Partially Observable Markov Decision Processes (POMDP), on-line optimization and network analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed models and numerical approaches for improving the management of infrastructure under uncertainty, accounting for factors which vary in space over the system domain and in time as the system changes. Adaptive schemes for optimal information collection for spatially distributed dynamic infrastructure systems are proposed and validated, including placement and scheduling of sensors, for series, redundant and general systems.  Optimality can be defined in terms of the value of information (VoI), which provides a rational metric for quantifying the benefits of data gathering efforts to support system management decision-making.  Some of these schemes are particularly effective for some special systems, when the economic costs decompose in a peculiar way.  Also, the projected has investigated when the VoI-metric exhibits the convenient property of “submodularity” (which can be intuitively understood as a diminishing returns property, whereby the incremental benefit of a specific observation is higher when the set of other available observations is smaller) and has proposed heuristic approaches applicable also when submodularity is not formally satisfied.

Overall, information collected by monitoring systems can provide a significant economic benefit to the operation and maintenance of infrastructure components only under specific conditions. The information must be precise, not redundant, related to relevant decision problems under uncertainty as, for example, the appropriate scheduling of maintenance actions, and the decision maker needs to be able to process that information and react timely.  This project has quantitatively investigated the relation between the VoI and key features of the monitoring system, of the component deterioration and of the decision-making process, including measure accuracy and availability, deterioration rates, damage predictability, reaction time, maintenance costs, and the economic discount factor.  The developed approaches are useful to identify conditions when the benefit of monitoring is high, to assign priorities among components that deserve to be instrumented or to optimize the allocation of resources to monitoring efforts.

These approaches are relevant for designing schemes of Structural Health Monitoring (SHM) and control of infrastructure systems, where measures of structural condition are collected by visual inspections and sensors, and maintenance and repair actions are taken with the goal of optimizing an appropriate metric of utility or loss.

As illustrative examples of the projects’ results, Fig.1 shows a comparison of the VoI of inspecting one or the other component in two-component series systems, depending on the correlation coefficient (between the states of the components) and on the probabilities of failure (p1 and p2 refer to component 1 and 2, respectively). The approaches developed in the project allow for assigning inspecting priorities depending on features as the correlation coefficient. Fig.2 shows an example of application of the developed approach for sensor placement across two spatially distributed components, overcoming the issue of submodularity, and comparing its performance with those of alternative approaches.

Fig.3 and 4 refers to applications to long-term processes of maintenance and control of infrastructure systems, accounting for sequential learning and decision making. Fig.3 shows the belief domain for the current state of a 4-state component, where states 1,2,3,4 refer to intact, slightly damaged, heavily damaged and collapsed conditions (when the probability of state 4 is zero). In this domain, it reports the additional expected economic benefit of having more precise sensors in the long-term discounted maintenance process. Fig.4 illustrates how the VoI varies as a function of some relevant features of the maintenance process, i.e. the inaccuracy of measure (a), the standard deviation of damage time according to the prior model (b), the needed reaction time of repair (c) and the repair cost (d).  These results allow for estimating the long-term benefit of installing a SHM system, and therefor for allocating effectively economic resources for monitoring campaigns.
